subject: JFCUnit, GUI testing with JUnit... Re: Best Practice for Tests ?

messageBody:
Thanks to David and Rob for the input. Dave is right, JFCUnit is not
100% the same as having a person use the keyboard and mouse.
Instead, JFCUnit tries to get reasonably close and make the test code
easy to develop and maintain. Hopefully this will make it easier for
teams to write GUI tests and therefore test more than they could in
the past.

Maybe JFCUnit could have an option to use Robot for creating the
events. Why don't you add it as a feature request?

- Greg



--- In junit@y..., Robert Sartin <sartin@a...> wrote:
>
> --- David Herron <davidh@7...> wrote:
> > I just downloaded and looked at their code. They have a fatal,
from
> > my perspective, flaw. Namely, to generate events against the
> > components they create a Java level event and post it to the
event
> > queue like so:
>
> I think the lesson here is that testing a GUI framework has
completely
> different needs from testing a GUI application. Having tried to use
> java.awt.Robot to test an application, I prefer the style of
jfcunit.
>
> One man's fatal flaw is another man's feature.
>
> Regards,
>
> Rob
